modules.text: AQuest is a Creative Production & Technology Company, capable of delivering high-impact web and multimedia experiences. I was a Frontend Developer at AQuest from 2015 to 2018. This project involves the complete re-design of the institutional website.

modules.title: The challenge
modules.text: In 2017, when we decided to redo the site, there were no verticals in WebGL at AQuest. We decided to take advantage of that opportunity to do training while simultaneously creating something with a strong visual impact that matched WebGL experiences typical of competitors who had been specializing in this technology for years, while maintaining all the SEO features of a corporate site.

modules.title: The attention to detail
modules.text:
All pages of the site had to have the same attention to detail, no matter how much they would be visited.

Here in the cases, for example, to listen to the audio that characterizes an experience, we made components that simulate strings. Page 404 contains the game Pong, and as you navigate the pages, the texts tilt according to the speed of your scroll.

modules.title: Not only creativity
modules.text:
This project not only meant creativity from a visual point of view, but it was also an opportunity to experiment with new development tools.

The entire frontend codebase is in fact written in Flow, which in 2017 aimed to make javascript and in particular React (Flow itself being developed by Facebook) a typed language.

To handle asynchronous events (data requests, animations, audio effects, transitions, etc.) we embraced the reactive paradigm making heavy use of RX.js
